creator: gurra16@spray.se
text:
It would be useful if you could give directives to the php auto_prepend_file, so
that it could run before any given file type. That is, even a given file type
that is not supposed to be parsed by php. Like an image file for example. You
may want to run a script before showing the image, but you don't want the image
content itself to be parsed by php.

This is a PHP enhancement request, not an HTTPD one.
Please use the bug system at bugs.php.net to request this.
creator: thom@planetarytramp.net

text:
But isn't it httpd that controls when php should be called in, based on the
httpd.conf settings, like AddType ?. After all, php is just a module to httpd.
As I see it, it must be httpd that decides what to do, when a file is requested
from the server. Php can't do that. Correct me if I'm wrong.
creator: gurra16@spray.se

text:
Nope.  PHP ties into the apache configuration system, but it is entirely
responsible for what files it processes.  This is clearly an issue for
PHP, not apache.
creator: slive@apache.org
